title: Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield star in mental health advert
text:
Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield are among the ITV faces who have taken part in a hard-hitting mental health campaign.

The broadcaster has conducted a Britain Get Talking survey which revealed that half of parents are worried about their children’s mental health.

Britain Get Talking is ITV’s five year social purpose strategy to support mental wellness. It was first launched on Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions the final with presenters Ant and Dec stopping the show to make the announcement.

The latest advert sees some familiar faces fall silent to encourage families to be more open about their feelings and catch up with one another.

Alongside the This Morning presenters are Dermot O’Leary. Jonathan Ross, Robert Peston, Emmerdale’s Mark Charnock and Emma Atkins and Loose Women stars Nadia Sawalha, Saira Khan and Kaye Adams.

To support the campaign ITV has also launched a Britain Get Talking website, which you can visit here.

Holly and Phil appear alongside famous faces in the advert (Picture: ITV)

Dermot O’Leary also appears(Picture: ITV)

Speaking about the campaign on Britain’s Got Talent, Declan Donnelly, 44, said: ‘In the last 15 years, there has been a staggering 48% rise in anxiety and depression amongst British children, but something as simple as talking together and listening to each other can build our mental wellness.’

Co-host Ant McPartlin, 43, continued: ‘Now, we all know that these days there are more distractions than ever because we’re looking at the telly or we’re looking at our phones.

‘But it’s so important for our mental wellbeing to remember to get together and with people we care about and talk.’

Chief executive of Mind, Paul Farmer, said: ‘We all have mental health, just as we all have physical health, and we can learn to look after it. At a time when only a third of people with a mental health problem get access to any kind of help and support, it’s important to do whatever we can to help people take steps to stay well and try and prevent mental health problems developing in the first place. Encouraging families to focus on the wellbeing of the next generation is a fantastic place to start.’
